awd_titl_txt: Claisen and Mitsunobu functional graphenic materials as stem cell instructive 3D printed scaffolds for bone regeneration
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Abstract:
This project aims to develop a resorbable scaffold that supports the bone regrowth after injury. Stem cells hold great promise to enable bone regrowth, but current scaffolds lack the ability to retain and provide signals to stem cells to enable their transformation into bone-forming cells at the site of injury. To overcome these limitations, functional graphenic materials (FGMs) hold promise. Graphite is abundantly available and can be chemically modified to form FGMs. FGMs offer excellent and tunable mechanical properties, degradability, and controllable surface chemistry that can be translated to tunable bioactivity. However, this is not yet possible because a suitable processing method does not exist. Here, the PI will develop new FGMs with the ability to retain and direct the healing response of bone-forming cells. Further, the PI will develop 3D printing methods for these FGMs to create personalized scaffolds for patients. Ultimately, FGMs could replace permanent hardware used in the surgical treatment of traumatic bone injury with a resorbable material that allows regeneration of natural bone. Beyond societal impacts, undergraduate and graduate students will be trained in the classroom and laboratory, as well as perform outreach activities to empower and engage women and underrepresented populations.


Technical Abstract:
This project aims to develop novel methods to synthesize and 3D print biomimetic, functional graphene materials (FGMs) that will serve as scaffolds for instructed stem cell regeneration of bone. Current methods for stem cell driven regeneration are limited because a scaffold that recruits stem cells and supports their retention as they differentiate into functional tissue. FGMs offer a unique panel of properties not found in any other single material and therefore has the potential to overcome these limitations. Specifically, FGMs offer autodegradability, mechanical properties, and long range order, coupled with controllable surface chemistry. Graphene oxide (GO) offers a plethora of organic functionality that can be used to tune the surface chemistry to maximize cellular interactions biocompatibility in FGMs. However, realization of these properties has been limited due to insufficient control of the chemical interface, and applications have been limited by an inability to produce a robust 3D scaffold. Here, new methods will be developed to create biomimetic FGMs by using the Claisen rearrangement and the Mitsunobu reaction: classic organic reactions to covalently install biomimetic moieties directly at the surface of the biomaterial. At the end of this funding period, the project will: 1) Demonstrate the ability of Claisen Graphene, CG, to create an instructive surface to promote superior stem cell adhesion. 2) Demonstrate superior stability of proteins, directed stem cell differentiation, and covalent controlled release using Mitsunobu Graphene, MG. 3) Innovate 3DP methods to produce FGM scaffolds suitable for implantation in vivo. Overall, this work on bone will provide valuable insights on stem cell directing therapies and could unlock the potential of stem cell directed regeneration in a plethora of tissue engineering therapies. Beyond societal impacts, this project supports ChemCast, a podcast designed to keep students up to date on research topics as well as outreach activities including the "Chemistry of Cycling".

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to create a scaffold that enabled stem cell-driven regeneration by recruiting and retaining stem cells at the site of injury as they differentiate into bone and other tissues. Composite materials containing biomimetic chemical moieties mimic the complexity found in native bone and can be designed to emulate the chemical properties of native tissue, as well as enhance the mechanical properties of potential grafting materials. Thus, the aim of this project was to develop novel methods to synthesize and 3D print biomimetic, functional graphene material (FGM) scaffolds for stem cell instructed regeneration of bone.

Functional graphenic materials (FGMs) offer a unique panel of properties not found in any other single material and through this proposal, we will amplify these properties. Specifically, FGMs offer 1) Autodegradability. FGMs follow an aqueous degradation pathway mirroring natural degradation of organic matter, suggesting good clearance, compatibility, and the potential to be fully replaced by regenerated tissue. 2) Mechanical properties and long-range order. Graphene is inherently strong and ordered by van der Waals interactions, imparting mechanical strength and biomimetic order to scaffolds. 3) Controllable surface chemistry. GO offers a plethora of organic functionality that can be used to tune the surface chemistry to maximize cellular interactions and biocompatibility. However, realization of these properties has been limited due to insufficient control of the chemical interface, and applications have been limited by an inability to produce a robust 3D scaffold.

Recent work has found that chemical moieties, specifically small molecules and peptides, induce osteogenesis (the formation of bone) without the use of growth factors, leading these pluripotent cells to their specialized function. This work developed FGM scaffolds to administer these small molecules in a sustained fashion at the site of bone regeneration. Specifically, we applied the Claisen reaction to allow stable installation of moieties to instruct cell attachment and differentiation directly at the tissue-scaffold interface. As a complementary chemistry, we developed the Mitsunobu reaction to install labile linkers that allow the controlled release of biological signals to instruct stem cell differentiation. Finally, we demonstrated the cell-instructive abilities of these FGMs in vitro and developed 3D printing methods to enable application of these materials as a functional scaffold.

Beyond these intellectual aims, the duration of this award covered the period of the COVID-19 pandemic, which allowed unique opportunities for broader impact. While labs were closed, the 3 PhD students funded by this project, as well as 6 undergraduate students, worked together to create a set of hands-on lab modules teaching principles of polymer and materials chemistry that could be taught in a fully remote environment. This work was published, and the following year, the course was taught at Carnegie Mellon, providing an educational experience for 5 additional undergraduate students.


Last Modified: 02/06/2025
Modified by: Stefanie A Sydlik
